intro.description: Welcome to the MetaWare IDE Standard Make tutorial. Running through this tutorial will help you understand how to create a new project and have the MetaWare IDE use the makefile within your build environment!

item.title: Create a Project
item.description: Create a C/C++ project by selecting the menu item File > New > Standard Make C Project.

item.title: New Project Wizard
item.description:
The New Project wizard starts.
Enter a project name, such as HelloWorld, for the new project.
You can also enter a new path for your project by deselecting the "Use Default" checkbox and entering the new path in the Directory: text box. Click Next.

item.title: Project Settings
item.description:
The Projects tab appears first. Here you can select other referenced C/C++ projects. Because this is a simple Hello World project, you do not need to make any selections here.
Click Next.

item.title: Make Builder
item.description: Click the Make Builder tab. Note that the MetaWare Development Toolkit uses gmake, which is selected by default.

item.title: Error Parsers
item.description: Click the Error Parsers tab. Here you can select the error parsers you require for a project and change the order in which error parsers are called. For this tutorial, you can leave all parsers selected.

item.title: Binary Parser
item.description: Click the Binary Parser tab and select the binary parsers you require for the project. You can also change the order in which binary parsers are called. For this tutorial, you can leave only the ELF Parser selected.

item.title: Discovery Options
item.description: Click the Discovery Options tab. This tab defines the configuration for autodiscovery of include paths and preprocessor symbols for the parser to enable the parser to understand the contents of the C/C++ source code. This helps you more effectively use the search and code completion features. Make sure ARC C/C++ Compiler Specs Parser is selected under "Command output parser".

item.title: C/C++ Indexer
item.description:
You can enable or disable the C/C++ Indexer here. The indexer is necessary for search and related features, like content assist and refactoring. While there may be situations where the indexer is not required, for this project you can leave it enabled.
When you have completed setting your C/C++ project preferences, click Finish.

item.title: New Project
item.description: You should now see the new project in the C/C++ Projects view.

item.title: Create a Makefile
item.description: Create the makefile by right-clicking your project and selecting New > File.

item.title: New File Wizard
item.description:
You now see the New File wizard.
Enter makefile as the name of the file in the File name text box, and click Finish.

item.title: New Makefile
item.description: You now see the empty makefile in the Projects view under the project, and makefile is open in the Editor view.

item.title: Enter the Make Script
item.description:
Enter the build instruction for the makefile you just created. The Outline view updates to display the structure of the makefile as you add components. When you enter the code, note the asterisk in front of the file name on the tab in the Editor view. The asterisk tells you the file was changed but has not been saved.
Note: Ensure you have tabs, not spaces, before your indented code, as gmake does not accept spaces before commands.

item.title: Create a C File
item.description: Create the hello.c file by right-clicking your project and selecting New > File.

item.title: New File Wizard
item.description:
The New File wizard appears.
Enter hello.c in the File name text box and click Finish.

item.title: New C File
item.description: "hello.c" is now listed in the Projects view under the project, and the empty file is open in the Editor view.

item.title: Enter Code
item.description:
Enter the code in the hello.c file you just created. You can double-click the hello.c tab in the Editor view to expand the view.
Note the asterisk in the Editor tab next to each filename. It indicates that changes to the file have not yet been saved.

item.title: Build the Project
item.description:
By default, your project is built on save. To build, save the files by selecting File > Save All or pressing Ctrl+Shift+S.
If you disabled "Build automatically", you can build manually by selecting Project > Build All (Ctrl+b).
Read through the build messages in the Console view. If any errors occurred, you can see them in the Problems view.

item.title: Run the Application
item.description:
The executable is now listed in the C/C++ Projects view with all other files in the project.
You can run your application within the C/C++ perspective by creating a "run configuration." To do so, select Run > Run....

item.title: Run Configuration
item.description: The initial Run dialog appears. Make sure C/C++ Local Application is selected in the Configurations: view, and click New.

item.title: New Configuration
item.description:
Make sure HelloWorld is selected in the Configurations: view and click the Main tab. This is where you select your C/C++ application and other settings that will impact how your application is run.
If the program is not specified, click Search and locate HelloWorld.elf.

item.title: Manage Configuration
item.description:
HelloWorld.elf now appears in the C/C++ Application: text box. The other tabs allow you to make additional settings. For the tutorial, accept the defaults.
Click Run to run the application.

item.title: Console View
item.description:
Output from the application appears in the Console view.
If your project contains multiple applications, the title bar of the Console view shows which application is running.
Because HelloWorld is a short application, it runs to completion.
